title: Why Mid-Market Companies Should Use Dynamic Pricing ​
description: Big companies have been using dynamic pricing for years. Here’s how smaller companies can benefit.
author: Marc Emmer
excerpt: Big companies have been using it for years. Whether consumers like it or not, dynamic pricing is here to stay.
text: Last February, in a debacle that will be taught in business schools for years, Wendy’s announced that it would be moving toward dynamic pricing. The backlash was swift and fierce, igniting intense debates across social media and rattling investor confidence. It was curious that critics overlooked comparisons to hotels, airlines and concert promoters who have been using this tactic for years. A restaurant selling fresh fish in Boston or Seattle can set its prices daily, but for a public fast-food operator, the idea of changing prices based on demand struck a nerve. While Wendy’s appeared tone-deaf in how it positioned dynamic pricing, we are moving toward a world where it will be more readily accepted by consumers. As a reality in a supply-shock world, many restaurants and retailers are moving toward electronic menu tags. Airlines are implementing dynamically priced loyalty points. Amazon dynamically prices…well, everything. And Facebook and Google ad prices are entirely set by the market.  As a practical matter, when a rideshare company uses surge prices, it creates an incentive for drivers to come to the platform, and a disincentive for riders to leave. This rebalances supply and demand so that the system can return to equilibrium. Today, markets experience swings in raw materials, weather, and labor. If, say, a food product is overpriced, it could be thrown away instead of consumed. Whether consumers like it or not, dynamic pricing is here to stay.  Real-World Examples of Dynamic Pricing  Several mid-sized companies have successfully implemented dynamic pricing strategies to optimize revenue and market positioning:​ Qcue: Revolutionizing Ticket Pricing in Live Entertainment  Austin-based Qcue has pioneered dynamic pricing solutions for the live entertainment industry. By enabling organizations to adjust ticket prices in real-time based on demand, Qcue helps maximize revenue and attendance. For instance, Major League Baseball teams like the San Francisco Giants have utilized Qcue’s technology to implement dynamic pricing across their venues, resulting in optimized ticket sales and improved fan experiences.  Zenrez: Enhancing Fitness Class Bookings  Zenrez, a company offering dynamic pricing solutions for fitness studios, allows businesses to adjust class prices based on demand and duration of session. This approach helps studios fill more spots by offering lower prices for less popular time slots, thereby increasing overall revenue and class utilization rates.  Holiday Retirement: Optimizing Senior Living Rent  Holiday Retirement, in collaboration with Prorize LLC, implemented a dynamic pricing model to optimize rent across over 300 senior living communities. This strategy led to a consistent and proactive pricing process, resulting in a revenue increase of over 10 percent.  Benefits of Dynamic Pricing for Mid-Market Companies Implementing dynamic pricing offers several strategic advantages:​  Revenue optimization: Adjusting prices based on real-time demand allows companies to maximize revenue, especially during peak periods.​  Enhanced competitiveness: Dynamic pricing enables businesses to respond swiftly to market changes, maintaining a competitive edge.​  Improved inventory management: By aligning prices with demand, companies can better manage inventory levels, reducing overstock situations.​  Challenges and Considerations While dynamic pricing presents significant benefits, private companies should be mindful of potential challenges:​  Customer perception: Frequent price changes can lead to perceptions of unfairness among customers. Transparent communication about pricing strategies is essential to maintain trust.​   Technological infrastructure: Implementing dynamic pricing requires robust data analytics capabilities and integration with existing systems, which may necessitate investment in technology and skill development.​  Market sensitivity: Over-reliance on dynamic pricing without considering market nuances can lead to pricing errors. A balanced approach that combines data-driven insights with market understanding is crucial.​  Dynamic pricing has emerged as a valuable strategy for companies seeking to enhance profitability and adapt to changing market conditions. By learning from successful implementations and carefully considering the associated challenges, we can find a middle ground where both consumers and providers benefit from dynamic pricing.  Ultimately, the invisible hand will necessitate that arbitrary pricing be set by supply and demand. html:
Last February, in a debacle that will be taught in business schools for years, Wendy’s announced that it would be moving toward dynamic pricing. The backlash was swift and fierce, igniting intense debates across social media and rattling investor confidence. 

It was curious that critics overlooked comparisons to hotels, airlines and concert promoters who have been using this tactic for years. A restaurant selling fresh fish in Boston or Seattle can set its prices daily, but for a public fast-food operator, the idea of changing prices based on demand struck a nerve. 

While Wendy’s appeared tone-deaf in how it positioned dynamic pricing, we are moving toward a world where it will be more readily accepted by consumers. As a reality in a supply-shock world, many restaurants and retailers are moving toward electronic menu tags. Airlines are implementing dynamically priced loyalty points. Amazon dynamically prices…well, everything. And Facebook and Google ad prices are entirely set by the market.  

As a practical matter, when a rideshare company uses surge prices, it creates an incentive for drivers to come to the platform, and a disincentive for riders to leave. This rebalances supply and demand so that the system can return to equilibrium. Today, markets experience swings in raw materials, weather, and labor. If, say, a food product is overpriced, it could be thrown away instead of consumed. Whether consumers like it or not, dynamic pricing is here to stay.  

Real-World Examples of Dynamic Pricing  

Several mid-sized companies have successfully implemented dynamic pricing strategies to optimize revenue and market positioning:​ 

Qcue: Revolutionizing Ticket Pricing in Live Entertainment 

Austin-based Qcue has pioneered dynamic pricing solutions for the live entertainment industry. By enabling organizations to adjust ticket prices in real-time based on demand, Qcue helps maximize revenue and attendance. For instance, Major League Baseball teams like the San Francisco Giants have utilized Qcue’s technology to implement dynamic pricing across their venues, resulting in optimized ticket sales and improved fan experiences.  

Zenrez: Enhancing Fitness Class Bookings 

Zenrez, a company offering dynamic pricing solutions for fitness studios, allows businesses to adjust class prices based on demand and duration of session. This approach helps studios fill more spots by offering lower prices for less popular time slots, thereby increasing overall revenue and class utilization rates.  

Holiday Retirement: Optimizing Senior Living Rent 

Holiday Retirement, in collaboration with Prorize LLC, implemented a dynamic pricing model to optimize rent across over 300 senior living communities. This strategy led to a consistent and proactive pricing process, resulting in a revenue increase of over 10 percent.  

Benefits of Dynamic Pricing for Mid-Market Companies 

Implementing dynamic pricing offers several strategic advantages:​ 

  • Revenue optimization: Adjusting prices based on real-time demand allows companies to maximize revenue, especially during peak periods.​ 
  • Enhanced competitiveness: Dynamic pricing enables businesses to respond swiftly to market changes, maintaining a competitive edge.​ 
  • Improved inventory management: By aligning prices with demand, companies can better manage inventory levels, reducing overstock situations.​ 

Challenges and Considerations 

While dynamic pricing presents significant benefits, private companies should be mindful of potential challenges:​ 

  • Customer perception: Frequent price changes can lead to perceptions of unfairness among customers. Transparent communication about pricing strategies is essential to maintain trust.​  
  • Technological infrastructure: Implementing dynamic pricing requires robust data analytics capabilities and integration with existing systems, which may necessitate investment in technology and skill development.​ 
  • Market sensitivity: Over-reliance on dynamic pricing without considering market nuances can lead to pricing errors. A balanced approach that combines data-driven insights with market understanding is crucial.​ 

Dynamic pricing has emerged as a valuable strategy for companies seeking to enhance profitability and adapt to changing market conditions. By learning from successful implementations and carefully considering the associated challenges, we can find a middle ground where both consumers and providers benefit from dynamic pricing.  

Ultimately, the invisible hand will necessitate that arbitrary pricing be set by supply and demand. Eventually, consumers will come along for the ride.  

The opinions expressed here by Inc.com columnists are their own, not those of Inc.com.
